summary: This document is a series of FBI emails from March-April 2023 regarding a FinCEN request to deconflict the release of Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Jeffrey Epstein. The SARs are sought in civil lawsuits against JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank by Epstein victims and the U.S. Virgin Islands government. The FBI is asked to review a list of names from its investigation to object or not to their disclosure.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of a pending appeal, which is cited as a reason the USAO has not been releasing information.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a sex offender whose financial transactions are the subject of the SARs and the underlying civil lawsuits against the banks.

persons.name: Seamus
persons.context: Addressed in an email providing 10 additional names for deconfliction review.

persons.name: Robert Trivers
persons.context: Listed as one of 10 additional names provided by FinCEN for the FBI to review and potentially object to the release of information about.

persons.name: Graves
persons.context: Listed as a recipient (cc'd) on an email regarding the deconfliction request.

connections.description: Maxwell's pending appeal is directly linked to the Epstein case, indicating their legal matters are connected.
Trivers's name is among those referenced in the FBI's Epstein investigation (NY-3027571) and presented for deconfliction, suggesting a documented connection.

events.title: FinCEN Urgent Deconfliction Request
events.description: FinCEN requests the FBI to review names from its Epstein investigation to object or not to the release of related SARs in civil lawsuits against JPMorgan and Deutsche Bank.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Mentioned as a temporal marker; some SARs were filed roughly a decade after the transactions, but after Epstein's arrest.

events.title: Civil Lawsuits Filed Against Banks
events.description: An unnamed Epstein victim (and a class) and the U.S. Virgin Islands government file separate lawsuits against JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank for providing financial services to Epstein.

locations: Federal District Court for the SDNY (Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: FinCEN sought FBI deconfliction to release Epstein-related Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) to parties in civil lawsuits against JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank.
The U.S. Virgin Islands government and an unnamed Epstein victim (representing a class) are separately suing the banks for their role in facilitating Epstein's activities.
A pending appeal in the Ghislaine Maxwell case was cited as a reason the U.S. Attorney's Office had not been releasing information.
The FBI was provided a list of names from its investigation (NY-3027571), including 'Robert Trivers', to review for potential objections to disclosure.
The presiding judge indicated he might order the disclosure of the SARs if FinCEN did not authorize it, creating urgency for the deconfliction request.
